intro: Tithymalus mesopotamicus, commonly known as the Mesopotamic tithymal, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbel-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. It produces small, white or pale yellow flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
